value.title: Trace Excel Power Pivot using DAX Studio
value.excerpt: DAX Studio is an awesome tool! You can even use it to trace Power Pivot within Excel. Patrick shows you how!  üì¢ Become a member: https://guyinacu.be/membership   *******************  Want to take your Power BI skills to the next level? We have training courses available to help you with your journey.

value.title: Tracing your DAX queries in Power BI
value.excerpt: Learn how you can trace your DAX queries when trying to troubleshoot or optimize Power BI reports and datasets. There are a few options and Adam walks you through them.  DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/  SQL Server Management Studio: https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/ssms/download-sql-server-management-studio-ssms?view=sql-server-ver15

value.title: Using DAX to format a list of values in Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Alberto Ferrari joins Patrick to walk through how you can use DAX to format a list of values within Power BI Desktop. This takes the concatenate values quick measure to the next level.  Original Quick Measure video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SjSKCZtiNlI  Alberto's article - https://www.sqlbi.com/blog/alberto/2018/12/20/displaying-a-list-of-selected-months/

value.title: DAX Measures: Filter Context Explained in Simple Terms using the I.C.A.N. Principle

Principle. ==  I. Incoming Filters ==  C. CALCULATE does it‚Äôs Magic! ==  A. Apply relationships (filters flow Across relationships)

value.title: DAX Time Intelligence Functions for Beginners with Jeffrey Wangüî¥Talk Power BI LIVE
value.excerpt: Datetime related calculations are some of the most common, yet confusing, calculations for people who are new to Power BI. Source: http://chriszabriskie.com/preludes/ Artist: http://chriszabriskie.com/

value.title: Aggregated Table in Power BI   Using GroupBy Function in DAX
value.excerpt: There are many different ways you can create aggregations in Power BI, You can do it in the source (using the database t-SQL language), or using Group By operation in Power Query. You can also do it in DAX using some functions. One of the functions that can be used for grouping and aggregation is Group
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IWJn2jVyb2o" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Aggregated Table in Power BI with Extra Options   Summarize Function in DAX
value.excerpt: In the previous video, I explained how you can use GROUPBY function in DAX to create an aggregated table. In this video, I'll explain how you can use Summarize function for the same purpose. Summarize function gives you more control on how to create your aggregated table with some extra functions. Let's
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/6Lvy4S_EnAY" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Combining Tables in Power BI   Union Except and Intersect in DAX
value.excerpt: Power Query is often the engine used for combining data tables, especially using Merge or Append. However, sometimes, you might need to do that operation in DAX. An example of that is when you want to create that combination only virtually as part of a measure calculation that evaluates dynamically.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IPziqmQgJFw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Customers Grouped by the Count of their Orders ‚Äì Dynamic Segmentation in Power BI Using DAX Measures
value.excerpt: In the previous part of this video, I explained what is the segmentation challenge, when you want to group data based on the aggregated result, and I explained a static method of creating aggregated tables and creating a relationship to the main detailed table. However, the caveat of that method is the
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bRk0tofVn2c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Dynamic Banding or Grouping in Power BI   Using DAX Measures   Choose the Count of Bins
value.excerpt: Banding (or binning or grouping) is a scenario that can be implemented both statically and dynamically in Power BI. Dynamic banding means selecting the bin (or band) configuration, and the banding changes based on the user selection of the slicer. Imagine that we have a count of customers by their age
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LaBmDaf_PPM" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Find a Text Term in a Field in Power BI Using DAX Functions
value.excerpt: In Power BI, there are multiple ways of searching for a text term inside a text field, you can use Power Query for doing this operation or calculations in DAX. In this video, I'll explain some functions in DAX that you can use to do this calculation. Most of these functions can be used inside a measure

value.title: SUM vs SUMX What is the Difference of the two DAX Functions in Power BI
value.excerpt: Sum and Sumx are functions that often founded to be misleading for many Power BI users. As both functions are doing the aggregation, it seems a bit confusing what is the actual difference between these two. There are many blog posts and articles about each function. I always explain the difference with

value.title: Computing a measure in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: You can use DAX Studio to evaluate one or more measures in your data model. This is the first step to write, test, and debug your DAX measures in a productive manner.  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Connecting Excel to Power BI Desktop using DAX Studio
value.excerpt: You can connect Excel to Power BI Desktop copying the connection string from Power BI Desktop. Useful to test your model for Excel consumption before publishing to Power BI service.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MVuEzcK0Rag" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Formula engine and storage engine in DAX
value.excerpt: Understanding the differences between the formula engine and the storage engine is the first step to understand the performance metrics and optimize a DAX formula. Article and download: https://sql.bi/684038?aff=yt  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt The definitive guide to DAX:

value.title: How to debug a DAX measure
value.excerpt: Use DAX Studio to run and debug a DAX measure: fix a calculation issue in a more productive environment and then copy the right formula back in Power BI. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/ VertiPaq Analyzer: https://www.sqlbi.com/tools/vertipaq-analyzer/

value.title: Introducing DEFINE COLUMN in DAX queries
value.excerpt: Learn the syntax and the use cases of the DEFINE COLUMN statement in DAX. Article and download: https://sql.bi/696234/?aff=yt This syntax has been introduced in DAX since December 2020 and can be used in DAX queries only.  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/?aff=yt The definitive guide

value.title: Letter case sensitivity in DAX, Power BI and Analysis Services
value.excerpt: Power BI and Analysis Services are case-insensitive by default. Lowercase letters are identical to uppercase letters. This is mostly a good choice, but it also comes with unexpected consequences. In this video, we run through a set of queries to understand what to be aware of when working with a mixture
